posts.cooked:
As a security conscious user, having Signal natively, and properly, support Wayland would help me feel more confident in the product’s security.

Ideally, this would be something that would be checked on launch and ran according to the DE being used with no UI changes. Minimally, users would be able to update or use a user level .desktop file to update the application to work under Wayland with minimal UI changes.

Assuming you download using Signal instructions found online - Currently, if you run or set the Exec line = to /opt/Signal/signal-desktop --use-tray-icon --no-sandbox %U --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland --enable-features=WaylandWindowDecorations you’ll run into these issues -

  • The Icon doesn’t register correctly for my task bar. The icon does register correctly when I hit the super key and l look up signal. I believe this might be due to something like hard coding the icon path in the application’s logic, but I have no proof of that. I just don’t know what else would be causing it.
  • The close, minimize, and delete are set to the left and not the right
  • In general doing things like snapping the application to one side or using the header to drag it out of full screen will cause issues more often than if I don’t run it with this configuration. Note on this, I had the problem the first time and didn’t note what those issues were, and the next time I tried it (months later) I couldn’t notice any issue, so this might be resolved.

Here is a screenshot of what this looks like for me if I run this from my terminal. It is the same as if I update my Exec line in the .desktop file.

image1904×996 244 KB

You can see in the bottom left of the screenshot I have the signal desktop and then the generic gear icon that’s actually running Signal. In the top left of the Signal app, you can see the close, minimize, and maximize on the left instead of right.

Note, if you use flatpak you should be able to run the above using flatpak run org.signal.Signal --use-tray-icon --no-sandbox %U --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland --enable-features=WaylandWindowDecorations. I haven’t tested it though.

Some other notes in general -

  • I am opening this here since this ticket on Github seems to have been closed due to it being marked as a feature request and all feature requests were auto-closed as noted on this ticket
  • More Linux distros are moving to Wayland by default
  • Wayland is a more secure DE. Signal might be generally more secure compared to most messaging apps, but I would have to imagine that if it could run properly on Wayland it would be more secure overall than running as xwayland in Wayland. This does seem to be at least not rejected in a conversation here between a user and a Signal maintainer
  • I can’t find anything official, but it seems like support for this is already happening/being pushed for, it’s just not exactly official.
  • If you are interested, I walk through what the Exec line is doing here

Was looking into the icon issue and google led me here, but in the end the solution for the icon issue was here in this bug report: App icon not shown on GNOME under Wayland · Issue #6868 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

Changing the wmclass to signal (lowercase) resolved the issue for me.

I set my local .desktop file to:

[Desktop Entry]
Name=Signal
Exec=/opt/Signal/signal-desktop --enable-features=UseOzonePlatform --ozone-platform=wayland --enable-features=WaylandWindowDecorations --no-sandbox %U
Terminal=false
Type=Application
Icon=signal-desktop
StartupWMClass=signal
Comment=Private messaging from your desktop
MimeType=x-scheme-handler/sgnl;x-scheme-handler/signalcaptcha;
Categories=Network;InstantMessaging;Chat;

Awesome catch, I was able to get this working right with that simple change. Thanks for bringing that into this thread!

One thing to note though is that I don’t think your current Exec is properly running in wayland. When I run your Exec line and then use Xeyes, I’m able to follow my curser on top of Signal, indicating that there’s something non-wayland about it. When I run it with the exec I provided and your StartupWMClass, both the icon and the xeyes indicator go away.

It looks like for my use case anyway, I’m mostly just looking for the correction on where the min, max, and close buttons are, but at this point, it’s close enough for me to run daily and see if there are any other issues.

So, having tried this out the last couple of weeks I really haven’t noticed anything even close to showstopping!

Obviously the min, max, and close are still on the left side, but other than that I think most users wouldn’t notice any issues. Personally and almost assuredly niche issue I have - I have a hot key that simulates pressing the right mouse click which doesn’t work unless the mouse is on the screen for Signal app. I use this a lot when a word is misspelled with my text box input cursor on the word, run this hot key, and then the correct spelling is suggested as if I right clicked the mouse to get the suggestion. It allows me to keep my hand on keyboard, which I much prefer where possible.

I believe the problem is caused because the current set up is that the dialog box that pops up is where the mouse is, and I would assume in wayland, doesn’t allow this unless the mouse is within the Signal window. After seeing this, I notice many other applications have the dialog box popup where the misspelling or the input cursor is within the text box.

So, generally, I think Signal would need to make the update to render the min, max, and close as well as test this on other distros, but I think this is very close to something stable. I assume this is an issue on gnome because client side rendering stuff, but am not knowledgeable enough to test or prove that. Personally speaking, I would also hope that the dialog box issue is addressed.

I am absolutely sure that my system and use case doesn’t cover all edge cases, but I do think/hope this should serve as a decent proof of concept that Signal could move to launch directly under Wayland for those who want it, without it being that massive a lift!

I also want to re-iterate, I think it’s well within Signals mission (Protect free expression and enable secure global communication through open source privacy technology.) to do so unless they can prove that running under xwayland is just as secure, which I am not sold on.

So I would love someone else to chime in and confirm this, but I think the current set up is failing to actually make wayland work properly with Signal. I had noticed that my tray icon wasn’t working anymore and started to play around with it. The setting is now working without having to set the flag! However I was curious and tested xeyes on Signal and was able to tray my mouse on it, unfortunately…

I really haven’t tested if there’s a new way to make it work or anything else, but just want to see if this is just me or not

If you want to make sure signal runs under wayland I recomment to put this in your /etc/environment:

# Applications using Electron 28 or newer: Same as --ozone-platform-hint=[auto|wayland|x11]
# https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/wayland#Environment_variable
# https://www.electronjs.org/docs/latest/api/environment-variables#electron_ozone_platform_hint-linux
# https://releases.electronjs.org/release/v28.0.0#Features
# https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/39792
# https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/34937 (Since Electron 21)
ELECTRON_OZONE_PLATFORM_HINT=wayland

This makes all electron apps run wayland by default.

Further: Regarding the icon in the taskbar: This happens because the desktop file signal is named does not match it’s window id.

GitLab

Look at !2 - the Wayland app_id is signal...

So renaming the desktop file will likely fix your problem
